docs.lead_paragraph: A four-year accord calls for union jobs on the 737 Max in Washington State, and if it is approved by members, the union said it would no longer contest a nonunion plant in South Carolina.
docs.abstract: Boeing and the International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers reach four-year accord adding thousands of new jobs in Washington to build its 737 Max jet; union says if deal is approved by members, it will no longer contest a nonunion plant in South Carolina.
docs.snippet: A four-year accord calls for union jobs on the 737 Max in Washington State, and if it is approved by members, the union said it would no longer contest a nonunion plant in South Carolina.

byline.original: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE and CHRISTOPHER DREW

docs.lead_paragraph: A BROADER LOOK The AMR bankruptcy case is obviously about reducing cost. Labor cost is the point that the airline led with, but American Airlines also has a pretty old fleet of planes. Chapter 11 can help with all of this. More broadly, according to In Debt, one should expect that this will be one more step down the road of commodification of domestic airline travel. STEPHEN J. LUBBEN
docs.abstract: DealBook Online notes AMR bankruptcy is step toward commodification of domestic airline travel; notes Canada is concerned about plan by 13 financial institutions to buy TMX Group; comments on Diamond Foods' proposed acquisition of Procter & Gamble's Pringles brand of chips; notes Carl C Ichan is urging WebMD to buy back up to $1 billion of its stock as alternative to possible sale. Photo, Drawing (M)
